column1: Plath’s childhood, stories and storytelling were pervasive. [SEP] As a 2 1/2-year-old, Sylvia was intensely jealous of her sickly younger brother for consuming so much of her mother’s attention. [SEP] While the baby nursed, Sylvia sat nearby on the ﬂoor, impatient and unhappy. [SEP] Her mother discovered that she could defuse Sylvia’s envy with a game in which Sylvia spread out the newspaper before her, picked out all the capital letters on the page, and pretended, in a very grown-up way, to read—an achievement that attracted much parental admiration. [SEP] Sylvia’s mother often made up bedtime tales, serialized from one evening to the next. [SEP] Almost as soon as they could talk, Sylvia and her brother responded in kind with limericks, poems, and fantastic stories of their own. [SEP] On
column3: to their grandparents’ house and on long car trips, favorite books invariably came along, offering ready inspiration for the children’s imaginative creations.54 [SEP] Filmstar Charlie Chaplin’s mother was herself a talented comedy actress and singer. [SEP] As a young child, Charlie often accompanied her when she went to work at the theater. [SEP] As a result, playacting and impersonating became an early focus of Charlie’s pretending. [SEP] One evening during a performance, his mother’s voice failed. [SEP] In a pinch, the stage manager, who had seen Charlie at play, led the little boy onstage in her place. [SEP] Charlie continued his playacting unabated, which included songs, dances, and impersonations from his mother’s repertoire. [SEP] He was demonstrating the wares of his ﬁrst and best te

column1: Adivinanzas (Riddles) Adivinanzas are riddles. [SEP] Many Chicano children remember being entertained with riddles narrated by parents and grandparents. [SEP] A riddle is an intellectual brainteaser, in Spanish called a quebracabeza; facts are framed in the form of a question in such a way that the respondent cannot possibly know the answer. [SEP] An example in Spanish is, “Qué camina de cuatro patas por la mañana, dos patas en el medio día, y tres patas en la noche?” (What
column3: on four legs in the morning, two legs in the afternoon, and three legs at night?) The answer is man, who as a child, in the “morning” of life, crawls on four legs; as an adult

column1: When K is the maximum value, N - , as in Figure .a–c, then each gene influences the fitness contribution of every gene. [SEP] This is the totally interconnected system. [SEP] Since fitness values are assigned at random for the to the (K + ), or to the N input configurations when K = N - , it is easy to show that the resulting fitness landscape is fully random. [SEP] A main feature of random landscapes is that there are nearly exponentially many local peaks, indeed the number of local peaks is to N/(N + ). [SEP] For N = , there are local peaks on the landscape. [SEP] Finding the global peak by hill climbing is improbable, and the system becomes trapped on a local peak. [SEP] Other features include the lengths of
column3: via fitter neighbors to nearby peaks, which scales as the logarithm of N, and the way directions uphill dwindle on

column1: each organism has traits that are aected by many genes, the polygeny discussed above, and each gene aects many traits, the pleiotropy alluded to above. [SEP] It is interesting to note that were organisms to evolve to a position below but near the biological reality that is the proper analogue of the Ksat phase transition, such a location might well achieve the gradualism and capacity to persistently evolve that Darwin noted and that we observe. [SEP] Both the gradualism and capacity to evolve are related to the number of alternative assignments of true or false to the V variables that satisfy the Ksat normal disjunctive form. [SEP] If there are connected pathways from one such assignment via -Hamming-mutant neighboring assignments that all satisfy the normal disjunctive form, then adaptive
column3: via alternatives genotypes are available, all of which roughly generate the same organism. [SEP] Gradualism is achieved. [SEP] Polygeny and pleiotropy tune landscape ruggedness and deformability, which tune coevolutionary dynamics, perhaps to a self-organized critical state of an ecosystem. [SEP] There are, in short, dimly understood laws that allow the coevolutionary construction of accumulating complexity. [SEP] And it appears that such coevolution typically is self-organized critical. [SEP] The NK coevolutionary model is not the only example of a model exhibiting self-organized critical behavior of model ecosystems. [SEP] Bak and colleagues, Ricard Solé, and others have created elegant models aiming in the same direction. [SEP] In particular, Solé’s model comes closest to fitting the act

column1: the industry has been legitimized and regulated in an attempt to curb the most disturbing facets of exploitation and in order to address health concerns. [SEP] The prostitutes are entitled to regular health checks and are expected to pay taxes on their earnings — yet another example of the Dutch people’s trademark pragmatic approach when it comes to tackling society’s difficult issues. [SEP] The area is safe — except perhaps in the early hours of the morning — and filled with tourists. [SEP] The tree-lined canals and old narrow iron bridges are some of the prettiest in the city, and prostitutes ply their trade behind relatively discreet windows, not on the streets. [SEP] At ground level, seedy or amusing ( depending on your point of view) shops sell sex wares, attracting customers from all
column3: of life; but don’t get too distracted, else you’ll miss the rows of dainty gables, quirky wall plaques, and window boxes brimming with flowers, which give the whole area a cheery feel. [SEP] Don’t be surprised to find offices, shops, and restaurants living side by side with the brothels here — it’s all part of Amsterdam life. [SEP] At night the streets come alive with bars, clubs, and adult shows. [SEP] It is one of liveliest parts of the city after dark. [SEP] Just make sure that you stay on the busier and well-lit thoroughfares as you make your way back to your hotel.

column1: oy the thrill of winning or the dejection of losing. [SEP] Golf courses entice you to lower your handicap. [SEP] Tour buses plow a path around the attractions, and duty-free shops tempt you to buy that little luxury item you’ve been denying yourself for so long. [SEP] Hundreds of day-trippers cruise to both islands, eager to do it all before they have to get back on the boat. [SEP] On the smaller and more remote islands — called the Out Islands or Family Islands — intimate resorts cater to your every need and make it possible for you to forget about schedules, deadlines, and traffic jams. [SEP] The most difficult decision you’ll have to make is what to pick from the extensive dinner menu. [SEP] While the clubs and casinos may not play on into the night, during the day you’ll be worn out by
column3: along the beach and other strenuous activities, such as collecting sea shells, enjoying long lunches, and applying sunblock. [SEP] The whole trip could prove to be exhausting! [SEP] The lure of the Bahamas is, of course, as much about the sea as it is about the land. [SEP] The waters of the western Atlantic are still some of the clearest and most beautiful in the world. [SEP] In summer the shallows are glassy still and range from azure blue to emerald green; the deep ocean channels reflect a deep blue that can best be appreciated from the air. [SEP] The sandy shallows are ideal for swimming and snorkeling, and since the development of scuba (an acronym for self-contained underwater breathing apparatus) gear in the 1930s, the seas around the Bahamas have become a top destination for diving e

column1: ndara Kosaido Country Club are both top-class, staging tournaments which bring some of the world’s best players. [SEP] There’s a 9-hole course at Sanur, and at Lombok there is the 18-hole Suranadi course. [SEP] Many hotels offer their own tennis courts, some floodlit for evening use. [SEP] Air-conditioned squash courts are available at a few places. [SEP] As the sun starts to set, informal soccer and volleyball games between visitors and locals begin on the beach at Kuta, Tuban, and Legian. [SEP] Walking in the countryside is one of the great pleasures of Bali. [SEP] Don’t start at the southern resorts, which are a long way from the best scenery, but begin instead up in the hills, where it’s cooler. [SEP] In Ubud, the Bina Wisata Information Center or your hotel can give you information on
column3: along the Campuan Ridge, or through picturesque local rice fields. [SEP] Bookstores in Ubud sell detailed maps, including Bali Pathfinder and Ubud Surroundings, that will help guide you along country pathways. [SEP] Keep Walking Tours (<balitrade@denpasar.wasantara.net.id>) at the Tegun Galeri shop in Jalan Hanoman offers one- to seven-hour guided

column1: he monks hold an all-night vigil attended by crowds of people. [SEP] La Moreneta looks down from a gold-and-glass case above and to the right of the altar in the basilica, but the faithful can touch or kiss her right hand through an opening. [SEP] At 1pm and 7pm (except in July), the choir boys of the Escolanía, one of the world’s oldest music schools, founded in the 13th century, fill the basilica with their angelic voices. [SEP] The congregation joins in at the end of the service to sing Montserrat’s hymn, the Virolai, an expression of faith fused with a nationalist fervor. [SEP] Montserrat is also the goal of outdoor sports pilgrims like cyclists (who make the trip from Barcelona) and mountain climbers who ascend the spires of rock above the monastery. [SEP] From the monastery there are
column3: to other hermitages and a funicular to the cave sacred to the legend of the Madonna. [SEP] Statues and plaques line the paths. [SEP] Montserrat is an extremely popular place, so there are several bars and restaurants set up to feed the hordes. [SEP] Montserrat can be reached in spectacular fashion by train from Barcelona’s Plaça d’Espanya. [SEP] On arrival at the Montserrat station about an hour later, a cable car continues right up the side of the mountain to the monastery. [SEP] A much-less preferable bus service also operates from Barcelona by Transportes Julià (Tel. 93/490 40 00). [SEP] By car, leave Barcelona via the Diagonal and take the highway, direction Tarragona, exiting at Sortida 25.

column1: Recreation and Sports Bermuda is an ideal vacation destination for outdoor activities. [SEP] Summer brings warm (but not hot) weather and warm sea temperatures, making it ideal for diving, snorkeling, and other water sports. [SEP] On land, you can fill your day with tennis and golf along with long
column3: and beach activities. [SEP] In winter, the sea temperature makes it a little too cold for diving, but many visitors still enjoy swimming in waters warmer than at home, and all land activities are thoroughly enjoyable with the addition of a jacket or sweater. [SEP] The Bermuda Tourist Board produces Bermuda — What to Do, a comprehensive brochure with contact information and prices on a range of sporting activities. [SEP] Golf

column1: Another area for safe and picturesque walking is along the sand dunes behind the South Shore beaches. [SEP] These link the main public beaches (from Warwick Long Bay to Horseshoe Bay). [SEP] They also provide access to secret coves. [SEP] Park in any of the beach parking lots along the south coast to reach the paths. [SEP] For a personal touch, there are a number of guides who provide guided
column3: full of interesting details of local history. [SEP] Contact Bermuda Lectures and Tours (Tel. 234-4082; fax 238-2773) for further details or to arrange a custom itinerary. [SEP] Water Sports

column1: These two parks lie adjacent to each other, and are usually visited together — one entrance fee covers both. [SEP] The main attractions are their giant sequoias, many of them approaching 3,000 years old, and the spectacular rock scenery of Kings Canyon. [SEP] The forests offer a gorgeous array of dogwoods, sugar pines, and white and red firs, and a rich flora of orange leopard lily, lupine, bracken fern, chinquapin, and white corn lily. [SEP] Start at the Visitor Center at Lodgepole or Grant Grove, where you can pick up a map and information about the best forest
column3: and back-country hikes, and perhaps watch their interesting audio-visual presentations about the parks. [SEP] The best introduction to the forest is Congress Trail. [SEP] It’s an easy 2-mile (3-km) walk, but worth lingering over for a couple of hours to absorb the beauty of the largest living creations in nature. [SEP] The trail begins at the General Sherman Tree, the biggest of them all. [SEP] Measuring 274 ft (84 m) tall, 103 ft (31 m) around its base and still growing, it’s one of the largest living organisms in the world. [SEP] Reaching up for light well above the rest of the forest, the first branches start 130 ft (40 m) above the ground.

column1: Running southwest from the Parc de l’Esplanade, the broad, modern Grande-Allée runs past the Assemblée Nationale (provincial parliament), built from 1877–1886 in the favored style of the time, French Renaissance. [SEP] This has been the citadel of Québec’s quest for a special identity in or outside the Canadian Confederation, especially under Prime Minister René Lévesque. [SEP] On Boulevard St-Cyrille, the Grand Théâtre de Québec was inaugurated in 1971 as Québec City’s arts center and home of the Québec Symphony Orchestra. [SEP] Battlefields Park (Parc des Champs de Bataille, 390 rue de Bernieres) is devoted to the momentous battle on the Plains of Abraham that decided the fate of Québec in 1759. [SEP] Quite apart from its historical significance, the park offers delightful
column3: across the treelined fields. [SEP] In the center of the park you’ll see a massive Martello tower, built in 1805, as part of Québec’s new defenses against a potential American attack. [SEP] In a town where every monument seems like a political statement, rue Wolfe leads to one on the spot where General Wolfe was mortally wounded, while anonymous Québécois patriots have responded with a statue of Joan of Arc, off the Avenue George VI. [SEP] In the southern half of the park, the Musée de Québec possesses a first-rate collection of Québécois painting and sculpture, as well as historic furniture, jewelry, and gold and silver church ornaments. [SEP] The sculpture is principally from the 18th century, but the paintings range from the colony’s beginnings to the present day. [SEP] Look for the histo

column1: Tennis: Most urbanizaciones and large hotels have their own courts. [SEP] Public courts are few and far between. [SEP] Walking: All the islands except Fuerteventura and Lanzarote are good for serious walkers. [SEP] Guided
column3: and special trails are mapped out for those intending to walk Mount Teide on Tenerife, and local tourist information offices may be able to help with trails in other national parks. [SEP] Water Sports

column1: soon gives way to a lush forest of giant pines and eucalyptus trees. [SEP] Four km (21⁄2 miles) south at Las Raíces is where Franco met with his co-conspirators in 1936 (see page 20). [SEP] An obelisk in the forest commemorates the event. [SEP] As the road gains altitude and temperatures fall, the views become ever more spectacular. [SEP] The Mirador Pico de las Flores looks out over to the southeast and the Mirador de Ortuño offers a panorama of the northern coast. [SEP] Highest of all at over 2,000 m (6,562 ft), Mirador las Cumbres reveals Teide in all her glory. [SEP] The entrance to the National Park is El Portillo de las Cañadas, where there is a visitor center (open daily 9am–4pm). [SEP] If you wish to walk in the park, pick up a leaflet or ask for information about the daily guided
column3: . [SEP] Note that during winter the environment can become quite harsh, and you should never undertake

column1: Walking and Hiking This is an ideal island to put on your walking boots and take to the countryside. [SEP] You will be well-rewarded, with small remote villages, hidden churches, and a rural lifestyle to explore. [SEP] Though Cretans are bemused as to why anyone would want to hike without any purpose but the pleasure of it, they have a genuine welcome for travelers on foot. [SEP] Itineraries can range from easy flat short
column3: to steep mountain hikes, though it’s not advisable to head into the high peaks without a guide. [SEP] Gorge

column1: This is an ideal island to put on your walking boots and take to the countryside. [SEP] You will be well-rewarded, with small remote villages, hidden churches, and a rural lifestyle to explore. [SEP] Though Cretans are bemused as to why anyone would want to hike without any purpose but the pleasure of it, they have a genuine welcome for travelers on foot. [SEP] Itineraries can range from easy flat short

column1: e Lakeside neighborhood, jammed with cheap hotels and restaurants, is where most Westerners congregate to rent bikes, shop for Tibetan wares that are sometimes cheaper here than in the capital, and drink cheap beer. [SEP] On the airport side of town, there are several luxury hotels, and one of these, on the lake itself, is reached by a hand-drawn ferry. [SEP] This is a starting and ending point for trekkers, and as such is filled with a mix of people in anxious anticipation of their impending adventure and those who have recently returned from exhausting treks. [SEP] Everyone seems content to fill up on cakes and pies. [SEP] Day hikes are a popular activity here, with the most popular hike being that to Sarangkot to see Dhaulagiri and the Annapurnas from the viewing tower. [SEP] Other good
column3: include a visit to the Tibetan refugee camp at Tashiling and to the Peace Stupa atop the forested hill on the south side of the lake. [SEP] You can also take a boat out on the lake or walk to Devin’s Fall, where a river disappears underground into a steamy hole. [SEP] While most people look on this as a staging point for a trek, Pokhara is such a beautiful spot that it can be quite enough just to relax and enjoy the mountain scenery in the warm sunshine. [SEP] The road back to Kathmandu follows the Seti River for much of the way. [SEP] A side road makes it easy to visit Gorkha, ancestral seat of the Shah dynasty and city from which the unification of Nepal was begun. [SEP] Prithvi Narayan Shah’s large palace here has been restored by wood-carvers, and you can climb for half an hour up to th

column1: ting the visit in 250 b.c. of the Indian emperor Ashoka, a zealous convert to Buddhism. [SEP] Buddhist pilgrims from all over the world come to Lumbini, and in recent years the site has been developed into an international cultural and religious park with several hotels and numerous Buddhist temples built by the world’s various Buddhist countries. [SEP] Although few tourists stray from the Kathmandu-Pokhara-Chitwan focal points, it is possible to see something of the undeveloped west without walking three weeks to get there. [SEP] There are now several lodges at Royal Bardia National Park on the Karnali River. [SEP] This park was created specifically as a preserve for tigers, which, with a little luck, can be seen here more easily than at Chitwan National Park. [SEP] Elephant rides, jungle
column3: and drives, river rafting, and bird-watching keep visitors busy. [SEP] The Karnali gorge above Chisopani is especially beautiful and is noted for the size of the fighting mahseer carp taken by sport fishermen.
